not attracted in return?﻿
top_comment.author: Aero Windwalker

comments.text:
Maybe it's because, the one attracted by the other has found what he needs 
in view of reproduction, but the other hasn't.
Imagine a old rich man and a young beautiful lady. The old rich man is not 
very attractive in the point of view of reproduction. But the lady maybe 
just wants his money (maybe money makes think about a stable economic 
environment and so a good environment to reproduce in, or she just likes 
money! XD). At the other hand, the old rich man is attracted by the lady in 
the point of view of reproduction.
That is one way of seeing the things, show me more!
comments.author: Nidomy

comments.text:
+Aero Windwalker Great question. Attraction is just the beginning, so it 
casts a wide net. Men tend to be more attracted to a variety of women. This 
makes perfect biological sense. It's better to think she wants you and be 
mistaken, (this only hurts your pride) then to think she's not attracted 
when she is. When this happens you could miss your opportunity. 
Biologically this could be devastating, because you miss an opportunity to 
pass on your genes.  I realize this sounds primitive, but at this point we 
are operating on pre-programmed drives. I love your questions. Please visit 
my website at DawnMaslar.com ans ask some more. I create a blog/vlog to 
give you a more in depth answer.
comments.author: DawnMaslarTV

comments.text:

another voluptuous female.

comments.text:
The science is the same for homosexuals.  The chemical and physiological 
makeup of our brains are as unique as our outer physical appearance.  Any 
time you hear about the male brain vs the female brain, you have to 
remember that those are archetypal models of what it means to masculine and 
what it means to be feminine.  If everyone fit into those molds perfectly 
(which has already been proved that we don't all fit perfectly), we 
wouldn't have hermaphrodites or intersexed individuals, or even varying 
degrees of masculity/femininity amongst individuals.  Scientists have only 
recently discovered that our chromosomes don't always accurately indicate 
our gender (or sex).

 The dramatic power of dopamine to interfere with free will and create 
sexual (and other) compulsions became clear when patients took drugs that 
imitate dopamine.For example,a Frenchman who took such a drug to control 
Parkinson’s symptoms recovered a large settlement from a pharmaceutical 
company after the medication temporarily gave him compul- sive homosexual 
urges. (He was straight when not on the meds.)192 Another Park- inson’s 
patient suddenly found himself cross-dressing after seventy years of un- 
eventful heterosexuality. When doctors decreased his dosage of the

A person that likes someone out of the norm does not have anything wrong

comments.author: DawnMaslarTV

comments.text:
So which are those variables that contradict?
The whole point of this video is to explain how certain physical stimuli 
make you feel attracted to a "mate".
Your reply actually could confirm the things that are explained in this 
video.
It doesn't claim that someone has to be beautiful. Or thin, or big or small 
chested or of a certain race. Your personal visual cues for attraction are 
not necessarily things that are considered "beautiful" by today's beauty 
standards. Neither does it claim that one particular scent or voice 
resonates with you. You'll be attracted to someone that fills in the blanks 
that you are missing genetically. Like to a certain ratio to their body 
(like broad shoulders, strong bone structure/limbs when you yourself are a 
string bean), or to someone with a leptine deficiency who easilly stores 
fat if for instance your body tends to be better suited for ketonic 
metabolism. It's just nature's way of telling you that this person's 
genetic make-up and immune system would give your offspring the best 
chances on survival when combined. That's why a "healthy" smell for one is 
an unhealthy smell for another because our genetic make-up is different, 
and the way our body works often changes based on health issues and needs. 
Our health and body changes all the time. You may lack nutrients. You may 
have a dissease. Your body is just telling you that "this mate right now" 
would be a perfect match - right now -. That's why it can change overtime. 
But only if you follow up on those unconscious cues. Voice for instance 
gives cues about amounts of testosterone. If you have lots you may need a 
mate that doesn't. And the sound of voice is a subconsious cue to that.
Many people tend to focus on aestethical "beauty". And then they wonder why 
they are not as attracted to a "beautiful" person as they thought they 
would be, but got this unexplainable need for someone who might be 
considered "ugly" by others. :P
That's real attraction that is :)
comments.author: Layonee

top_comment.author: Ace Ventura

comments.text:
Ace, You are correct. There are other factors in attraction, but I couldn't 
fit everything in a short video.
comments.author: DawnMaslarTV

comments.text:
+Ace Ventura Ok fair points. I was knackered last night I don't think I 
took in what you said properly :P 

The point you didn't respond to was that we can't be sure if it's strictly 
true to say symmetry is attractive or whether there 
are subtleties/complexities because we don't know the exact mechanism in 
the brain or if it's the same for everyone etc. Studies done trying to find 
what is attractive can't be much more thorough than surveys where people 
pick the faces they are most attracted to. Which isn't all that accurate, 
It's rough and inconclusive. Those studies can be useful of course, being 
suggestive, leading to more studies, etc, but in terms of drawing 
conclusions they don't tell you 100% what constitutes attraction.

Owen Wilson hasn't had a nose correction that was just a computer generated 
nose + jaw correction.

The page you linked.. i don't find Keira Knightley attractive at all, which 
I imagine is because she is anorexic (not in good health, not ideal for 
reproduction, nor survival, etc). Yet the men chose her as attractive. The 
men who chose her likely did so for ingrained cultural reasons (weight 
loss/fitness/fashion industries idealizing overly thin body shapes and 
faces). Which shows me that their attraction to her was subjective more 
than anything. That is what I mean by the flaws in these studies.

Here's an empirical angle on beauty: 
http://www.joomag.com/magazine/mag/0916630001387119885?feature=archive
comments.author: PJ A

comments.text:
+PJ A I did.. I told you that I never said symmetry is the only thing that 
applies.

You were simply stating the obvious... So if anything I agreed with you. 
Saying symmetry is the only thing that is required for attraction is an 
oversimplification.

I also pointed out how balance and proportionality (aspects you said were 
more important than symmetry) is what makes a symmetrical shape.

I also given you an article that specifically states how important symmetry 
is to attractiveness.

All you have done was affirm my argument, while adding Owen Wilson's 
picture.

Oh BTW, even Owen Wilson must of disagreed with you about his face. Because 
after all, it was he who chose to correct his nose, it wasn't anyone else.
comments.author: Ace Ventura

comments.text:
+Ace Ventura sorry but your answer hasn't acknowledged my points so I am 
afraid I cannot acknowledge yours.
comments.author: PJ A

comments.text:
+PJ A I think its more to do with symmetry because symmetry is also 
important in determining whether a painting is beautiful, or a car is well 
designed. All stimulate the same region of the brain, namely the prefrontal 
cortex. 

However there are other factors that play a role in whose attractive or 
not. I never said symmetry is the be all quality in a beautiful face, or in 
choosing a mate. But it is one of few things you notice right away when you 
meet someone for the first time.

http://realdoctorstu.com/2011/03/16/the-science-of-attraction-what-makes-a-beautiful-face/

If you want to research more about the correlation of attractive faces, and 
paintings, look up nuroaesthetics.

BTW proportion and balance are all aspects of symmetrical shape, lol.... If 
one side isn't balanced with the other than it isn't perfectly symmetrical.
comments.author: Ace Ventura

comments.text:
+Ace Ventura "symmetry" is a massive oversimplification in my opinion and 
it shouldn't be implied that symmetry alone equates to visual attraction. 
If you make your face symmetrical by mirror imaging one side it becomes 
less attractive, so symmetry literally =/= attraction.

It must be a complex mixture of things - eg symmetry + proportion + etc - 
owen wilson in this image is showed with broken nose and with special 
effect nose correction: 
http://www.freephotoretouching.com/examples/images/001-30_repair-broken-nose-with-retouching_before-and-after.jpg 
Clearly, to me at least, he looks more attractive on the left, so maybe 
it's more accurate to say it's about proportion and balance. Maybe it's 
about facial muscles not being matched with the nose after the correction.

How can we know exactly what constitutes the attraction? I'm pretty sure no 
one actually knows the mechanisms in the brain behind visual attraction so 
when someone has done a study suggesting what is attractive (symmetry) it 
is flawed and inconclusive.
comments.author: PJ A

comments.text:
+Tenjamn I never said it didn't fall into sight... But attraction to 
symmetry is universal across cultures. That is why I think it's important 
to mention, and it's something most people wouldn't thought of.
comments.author: Ace Ventura

comments.text:
+Ace Ventura "Many visual beauty standards vary between cultures and eras." 
while symmetry can be important, it still falls under sight, it is the 
sense that you use to find symmetry.
comments.author: Tenjamn

comments.text:
+Tenjamn but they don't explain what it is through sight we look for. 
Symmetry is vital. Without it we are less likely to engage in either of the 
addition senses.
comments.author: Ace Ventura

comments.text: I believe that would fall under sight.
comments.author: Tenjamn

top_comment.author: Ida Magnusdotter Ganeteg

comments.text:

comments.author: Ida Magnusdotter Ganeteg

comments.text:
Hi Ida,
Here are the studies  and references I used for the video.

* Fisher, Helen. Lust, Attraction, an Attachment in Mammalian Reproduction. 
Human Nature, Vol 9, No. 1, pp23-52.

* Fisher, Helen et al. The Neural Mechanisms of Mate Choice: A Hypothesis. 
Neuroendocrinology Letters Special Issue. Supply 4, Vol. 23 December 2002.

*Buss, David et al. Sexual Strategies Theory: An Evolutionary Perspective 
on Human Mating. Psychological Review 1993, Vol 100, No 2, 204-232.

*Brizendine, Louann The Male Brain 2010 Random House New York, NY.

* Grammer, Karl et al. Human pheromones and sexual attraction. European 
Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Reproductive Biology. Vol 118, Issue 
2, Feb 1, 2005 135-142

* Miller, Saul et al. Scent of a Woman: Men’s Testosterone Responses of 
Olfactory Ovulation Cues. Psychological Science, 2009

*Cardiff University (2005, April 2). Love at First…Smell. ScienceDaily. 
Retrieved August 2, 2013.

*Penn, Dustin et al. The Evolution of Mating Preferences and Major 
Histocompatibility Complex Genes The American Naturalist Vol 153, No 2 Feb 
1999.

*Xu, Yi at al. Human Vocal Attractiveness as Signaled by Body Size 
Projection. PLoS One, 2013; 8 (4).

* Williams, Lawrence at al. Experiencing Physical Warmth Promotes 
Interpersonal Warmth Science 24 October 2008: Vol 322 no. 5901 pp. 606-607.

* Hughes, Susan et al. Sex Differences in Romantic Kissing Among College 
Students: An Evolutionary Perspective. Evolutionary Psychology. 2007 5(3): 
612-631.

captions.text: We like to think of romantic feelings

as spontaneous and indescribable
things that come from the heart.
But it's actually your brain

running a complex series of calculations
within a matter of seconds

that's responsible
for determining attraction.
Doesn't sound quite as poetic, does it?

But just because the calculations
are happening in your brain

doesn't mean those warm,
fuzzy feelings are all in your head.

In fact, all five
of your senses play a role,

each able to vote for,
or veto, a budding attraction.

The eyes are the first
components in attraction.

Many visual beauty standards vary
between cultures and eras,

and signs of youth,
fertility and good health,
such as long lustrous hair,
or smooth, scar-free skin,
are almost always in demand

because they're associated
with reproductive fitness.

And when the eyes spot
something they like,
our instinct is to move closer
so the other senses can investigate.
The nose's contribution to romance
is more than noticing perfume or cologne.

It's able to pick up
on natural chemical signals
known as pheromones.
These not only convey

important physical or genetic information
about their source

but are able to activate a physiological
or behavioral response in the recipient.
In one study, a group of women

at different points
in their ovulation cycles
wore the same T-shirts for three nights.

After male volunteers
were randomly assigned

to smell either one of the worn shirts,
or a new unworn one,

saliva samples showed
an increase in testosterone

in those who had smelled a shirt worn
by an ovulating woman.
Such a testosterone boost
may give a man the nudge to pursue a woman
he might not have otherwise noticed.
A woman's nose is particularly attuned

to MHC molecules,
which are used to fight disease.
In this case, opposites attract.

When a study asked women to smell T-shirts
that had been worn by different men,

they preferred the odors of those
whose MHC molecules differed from theirs.
This makes sense.

Genes that result in a greater
variety of immunities

may give offspring
a major survival advantage.
Our ears also determine attraction.

Men prefer females
with high-pitched, breathy voices,

and wide formant spacing,
correlated with smaller body size.

While women prefer low-pitched voices
with a narrow formant spacing
that suggest a larger body size.
And not surprisingly,
touch turns out to be crucial for romance.

In this experiment,
not realizing the study had begun,

participants were asked
to briefly hold the coffee,
either hot or iced.

Later, the participants read a story
about a hypothetical person,
and were asked to rate their personality.
Those who had held the hot cup of coffee

perceived the person
in the story as happier,

more social, more generous
and better-natured

than those who had held
the cup of iced coffee,

who rated the person as cold,
stoic, and unaffectionate.

If a potential mate has managed
to pass all these tests,
there's still one more:
the infamous first kiss,

a rich and complex exchange
of tactile and chemical cues,
such as the smell of one's breath,
and the taste of their mouth.

This magical moment is so critical
that a majority of men and women

have reported losing
their attraction to someone
after a bad first kiss.

Once attraction is confirmed,
your bloodstream is flooded
with norepinephrine,
activating your fight or flight system.
Your heart beats faster,
your pupils dilate,

and your body releases glucose
for additional energy,

not because you're in danger
but because your body is telling you
that something important is happening.
To help you focus,

norepinephrine creates
a sort of tunnel vision,
blocking out surrounding distractions,
possibly even warping your sense of time,
and enhancing your memory.

This might explain why people
never forget their first kiss.
The idea of so much of our attraction

being influenced by chemicals
and evolutionary biology

may seem cold and scientific
rather than romantic,

but the next time
you see someone you like,

try to appreciate how your entire body
is playing matchmaker

to decide if that beautiful
stranger is right for you.

title: The science of attraction - Dawn Maslar
